title: A Gap-ETH-Tight Approximation Scheme for Euclidean TSP

sections.more related work:
The framework of Arora  and Mitchell  was
employed for several other optimization problems in Euclidean space such as
Steiner Forest 1, k𝑘k-Connectivity 6, k𝑘k-Median  , Survivable Network Design 7. We hope our techniques will also find some applications in them. The original results from   was also applied or generalized to different settings.
The state-of-the-art for the Traveling Salesman Problem in planar graphs
is now very similar to the Euclidean case.  gave the
first PTAS for TSP in planar graphs, which was later extended by
 to weighted planar graphs. Klein 
proposed a 2𝒪​(1/ε)​nsuperscript2𝒪1𝜀𝑛2^{\mathcal{O}(1/\varepsilon)}n time approximation scheme for TSP in unweighted planar
graphs, which later was proven by Marx 5 to be optimal assuming ETH. Klein  also studied a weighted subset version of TSP that generalizes the planar Euclidean case and gave a PTAS for the problem. The literature then generalized the metrics much further. Without attempting
to give a full overview, some prominent examples are the algorithms in
minor free graphs  2 0,
algorithms in doubling metrics  3, and algorithms in
negatively curved spaces , each of which is at least
inspired by the result of Arora  and Mitchell . Recently, Gottlieb and Bartal  gave a PTAS for
Steiner Tree in doubling metrics. Moreover, they proposed a
2(1/ε)𝒪​(d2)​n​log⁡nsuperscript2superscript1𝜀𝒪superscript𝑑2𝑛𝑛2^{(1/\varepsilon)^{\mathcal{O}(d^{2})}}n\log{n} time algorithm for Steiner Tree in
d𝑑d-dimensional Euclidean Space with a novel construction of banyan. There is also a vast literature concerning Euclidean Spanners (see the
book 7 for an overview). Very recently Le and
Solomon 1 proved that greedy spanners are optimal
and in 2 they gave a novel construction of light Euclidean
Spanners with Steiner points. Many such results mention approximation schemes for Euclidean TSP as a major motivation.
